title: Conjugate Prior Distributions
description: Understanding conjugate prior relationships and their role in Bayesian inference and Active Inference.
learning_objectives: Apply conjugate priors in Active Inference models
Design Bayesian models with tractable inference

content.overview: Conjugate priors are prior distributions that, when combined with the likelihood, produce a posterior distribution of the same family. This property enables analytical computation of posterior distributions, making inference tractable in many Bayesian models.

mathematical_definition.conjugate_relationship: If p(θ) is conjugate to p(x|θ), then p(θ|x) ∝ p(x|θ) p(θ) is same family as p(θ)
mathematical_definition.posterior_form: p(θ|x) = p(θ|α', β') where (α', β') = (α, β) + sufficient statistics
mathematical_definition.sufficient_statistics: Summary statistics that capture all information about θ in data

common_conjugate_pairs.interpretation: Beta prior represents pseudo-counts of successes and failures

common_conjugate_pairs.likelihood: Gaussian: p(x|θ) = N(θ, σ²) with known σ²
common_conjugate_pairs.posterior: N(μₙ, σₙ²) with μₙ = (σ₀²μ₀ + σ²x)/(σ₀² + σ²)

common_conjugate_pairs.interpretation: Gamma prior represents pseudo-counts and exposure time
Gamma prior as conjugate for rate parameters

role_in_active_inference.generative_models: Conjugate priors enable tractable inference in hierarchical models

computational_benefits.analytical_updates: No need for numerical integration or sampling
computational_benefits.memory_efficiency: Store only hyperparameters, not full distributions
computational_benefits.online_learning: Sequential updates without storing all data
computational_benefits.predictive_distributions: Easy computation of posterior predictive distributions

limitations_and_extensions.nonparametric_alternatives: When conjugate priors are too restrictive

interactive_exercises.description: Compute posterior distributions for conjugate pairs
Design Bayesian models using conjugate priors

common_misconceptions.misconception: All Bayesian models need conjugate priors
common_misconceptions.clarification: Conjugate priors are convenient but not necessary
Posterior parameters may still be complex even if family is conjugate
Can encode strong prior beliefs while maintaining conjugacy
